title: Maximal Aerobic Function and Health
content: The importance of developing the aerobic system, defines maximum aerobic function (MAF), and explains how to determine your MAF heart rate. How to integrate that into a training protocol which is designed to help people move faster at a sub maximum heart rate and increase fat utilization as the primary source of fuel—emphasizing the importance of nutrition on one’s capacity to oxidize fat. The impact of a low-carb diet on one’s capacity for high intensity exercise and anaerobic performance, and explains the downstream effects of being “overfat.”

title: Fitness vs Health
content: The difference between being “fit” and being “healthy”.

title: Aerobic and Anaerobic Systems
content: Defining the aerobic and anaerobic systems, and why VO2 max doesn’t predict performance.

title: Maximum Aerobic Function (MAF)
content: Defining maximum aerobic function (MAF), determining your MAF heart rate with Phil’s 180 Formula, and why a strong aerobic system is crucial to health and performance.

title: Nutrition and Exercise
content: The impact of nutrition on one’s ability to use fat as fuel while exercising. Phil’s nutritional approach with patients, the concept of “carbohydrate intolerance”. Assessing the impact of a low-carb diet on high intensity exercise and anaerobic performance.

title: Overfat and Health
content: How being “overfat” affects health and performance, and ways to decrease excess body fat.

title: Training principles for longevity
content: Training principles for longevity

title: Preventing cardiovascular disease
content: The latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more

title: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin
content: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent

title: Alzheimer's disease and lifestyle factors
content: Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more.

title: Cancer risk and lifestyle factors
content: Cancer risk including the relationship between cancer and exercise as well as the link between alcohol consumption and cancer.

title: Exercise and protein consumption
content: Exercise and protein consumption as well as how her perspective has shifted as it pertains to fasting and time-restricted feeding.

title: The difference between being fit and being healthy
content: The difference between being fit and being healthy. Fitness and health are two separate definitions, and they need to be balanced whether you're a grandmother who goes out for a walk four or five times a week, or you're training for the race of your life as a professional.

title: Cardiovascular Health Monitoring
content: This was a functional test designed to monitor progress in cardiovascular health — Could people walk faster and faster over time at the same low heart rate than they could a month or two earlier.

title: Aerobic and Anaerobic Systems
content: Aerobic system: Fat burning is associated with aerobic. All of the factors that are associated with fat burning— the aerobic muscle fibers, the mitochondria, and the ability to convert fatty acids into energy (ATP). Anaerobic system: Using glucose (rather than fat) for making ATP. If you stay under a certain HR, you’re in an aerobic state.

title: VO2 Max and Performance
content: Despite common belief, VO2 max is not a great predictor of much. The fitter you are, the more oxygen you’re able to consume. A lot of people erroneously think this is a test of the heart and lungs, but it’s really a test of what your muscles can do in terms of utilizing that oxygen. The research actually says that you can’t predict marathon finish time by VO2 max.

title: Maximum Aerobic Function (MAF)
content: MAF stands for maximum aerobic function. In essence, the goal of being healthy and fit is to develop the aerobic system. This is what our ancestors did—we developed a really incredibly powerful aerobic system by doing the things in our lifestyle that drive that aerobic system to develop.

title: MAF 180 Formula
content: A person is going to be at their maximum aerobic output—meaning they’re going to be maximally fat oxidizing—at an approximate heart rate of 180 minus their age, plus or minus a few modifications. You begin with 180 minus your age and individualize it to your health and fitness needs.

title: MAF Test and Aerobic Fitness
content: Let’s say someone determine that their MAF heart rate is 130. At that heart rate, they are running at a nine minute mile pace. The question becomes: While keeping my heart rate at 130, can I get faster? Can they go from 9 minute mile to an 8:30 mile to an eight minute mile while staying at 130? By definition, that person will become aerobically fitter and more efficient.

title: Increasing Sub-Max Pace
content: For an endurance athlete, it’s the greatest benefit they can obtain. Because if they can go faster at a sub max pace, they can go faster at a max pace.

title: Nutrition and Fat Oxidation
content: When Peter was in medical school, the conventional wisdom was that fat oxidation could not exceed one gram per minute. Many years later, Peter adopted a strict ketogenic diet for several years. In his keto state, during VO2 max testing he hit a fat oxidation of 1.73 grams per minute just prior to reaching his VO2 max. He would go on to learn that world class athletes training on a very low carbohydrate diet were able to hit up to 2.2 grams per minute.

title: Sports Nutrition and Fat Burning
content: The conventional wisdom about sports nutrition and sports science is largely based on assumptions of what people are eating. Many of the subjects in the studies on this were big carbohydrate eaters that distorted the research completely. Despite the research data, there was experience with patients and athletes that informed that there was something about fat. Occasionally in the lab, athletes would come across that would make people say, Wow, this is amazing. How could this person burn so much fat? We don’t understand this. It must be a problem. But as the years went by, it was clearly not a problem at all—in fact it was a great thing. By staying close to his patients, it was always known that athletes were getting healthier— I know they’re burning more fat because they’re running faster at the same MAF heart rate. Then, gradually started thinking more scientifically about this… And the fat burning component became that factor that we can measure more and more. It was able to determine that this type of lower-intensity training and lower-carb eating impacted people’s capacity to burn fat.

title: Nutritional Component of Fat Burning
content: The confusing nature of the nutritional component to fat oxidation creates a lot of confusion for people, which is that it tends to be in flux. So it’s not constant. For example, between the ages of 13 to 18, one could eat as much food of any type that they wanted. But, by the time they were into their late 20s and 30s, tolerance for that amount of carbohydrate went down. Despite still exercising a ton, way more than most people, they become metabolically ill.

title: Carbohydrate Intolerance and Holism Approach
content: All become more insulin resistant as the years go by, but it is careful to refer to this as carbohydrate intolerance as people can better relate to that idea. Holism is the idea that all systems are connected and work in conjunction with each other. And more specific to patients, holism means weaving together exercise, nutrition and stress management. Measuring insulin resistance back in the 80s was basically unheard of. As a clinician, because you do a good evaluation, you assess the patient, and you spend a lot of time talking to the patient, and you learn about so many things, including insulin resistance.

title: The Two-Week Test
content: The Two-Week Test is a challenge for patients. Essentially, for two weeks, the patient removes all the junk food from their diet, and also cuts way down on the natural carbohydrates like lentils and beans and rice and fruits. After the two weeks, you looks at their symptoms and see if any are better. And in experience, about 75% of people get better. Next, you begin to add things back into the diet carefully to see at what point things start to trigger the bad symptoms again.

title: Impact of Low-Carb Diet on High Intensity Exercise
content: Spent several years on a very low carbohydrate diet and saw enormous improvements in aerobic fitness. Anaerobic fitness (higher level intensity fitness), did not deteriorate, but it took a very long time for that to come around. The conclusion drawn was that athletes who were very involved in glycolytic activity really ought not restrict carbohydrates as much as athletes whose sports are happening more at the aerobic level. However, a study found that very low carbohydrate intake did not deteriorate high-intensity performance.

title: Insights from World-Class Marathoners
content: Many world class marathoners acknowledge they might only have a dozen marathons in them in their entire career where they’re going to really be able to run at a certain level. If they were to spread those 12 marathons over 15 years, that’s a different philosophy than the churn and burn philosophy. Someone who is in their 30s, not somebody who could run a great 10K (anymore) but certainly could have been great in their 20s. But now in their 30s and even early 40s, they will have built a great endurance base.

title: Overfat and Its Impact on Health and Performance
content: The term overfat is preferred over overweight. It’s adipose tissue we should be concerned with, not mass. Waist circumference and waist to height ratio are suggested as a better indicators of metabolic health than BMI. The prevalence of overfat is estimated to be 91% in US adults and 69% in US children; Obesity is leveling off, but increases in abdominal fat are not.

title: Effects of Overfatness on Health and Performance
content: The overfat condition can typically add weight to the body, affecting running performance. Those with excess body fat can have serious downstream problems such as blood fat abnormalities, blood sugar abnormalities, blood pressure abnormalities, and ultimately chronic illness. This condition also impairs the immune system, leading to more frequent sickness. Physical impairment problems are also more frequent in people with excess body fat, ranging from simple injuries like plantar fasciitis to more severe pain patterns like low back pain and arthritides.

title: Reducing Excess Body Fat
content: Sugar consumption is actually declining, but it sometimes takes awhile for this decline to translate into health benefits. However, these things are multifaceted. For example, activity levels might be declining even while certain elements of nutrition improve, and so the net effect of that could be a reduction. Quality of sleep could also be declining, and that can offset any benefit that we see.

title: Health vs. Performance
content: Health and performance are not necessarily the same thing. Too often people that are not very healthy believe that the key to getting healthier is to train for a marathon, or an Iron Man. However, all a deconditioned person needs to do is start by walking around the block. The fat burning benefits that they’ll get from that simple act are huge. Food is more important and reducing stress is also a key factor. The final message is: Food and exercise are keys. And it’s really, really simple. Just don’t eat junk food, and take it easy out there.
